Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Urban Adaptation and its Role in the Success of Biological Invasion in Anolis Lizards
Award.AbstractNarration:
Urban areas are expanding rapidly around the globe, resulting in drastic changes to the environment compared to natural landscapes: buildings and parking lots replace natural vegetation in cities. The urban environment, which encompasses a major portion of the US, directly affects the ecology and evolution of species, but little research has been conducted to understand the intensity and scope of these effects. Another critical dimension of global change is biological invasions, which threaten biodiversity worldwide. This project connects two important dimensions of global change to test a novel hypothesis that urban adaptation may increase the success of biological invasions, which often have dramatic ecological and economic effects on the invaded habitats. This award will also support the STEM training of a postdoctoral researcher and numerous graduate and undergraduate students. Curriculum materials will be developed for K-12 education and outreach efforts will target the urban areas where this research will be conducted and where the research team members live.

The way organisms interact with their environment is expected to drive intense natural selection on their morphology and behavior. This work will study the crested anole lizard, which is native to Puerto Rico but established via human-mediated introductions in several places outside its natural range. This research will use field and laboratory studies to first test the hypothesis that a widespread lizard species is adapted behaviorally, morphologically, and physiologically to urbanization. Second, the study will test if adaptation occurs at multiple life history stages, including embryos and juveniles. Lastly, the study will investigate a novel idea in invasion biology that adaptation to urban environments may predispose populations to become successful invaders of other urban areas, using molecular data to identify source populations. Detailed portions of the research will estimate thermal tolerance and examine behavioral thermoregulation in different habitats, use SNPs to identify the source population of the invaders, and examine habitat influence on development in the field. This research will help to establish whether or not adaptation to urban areas can facilitate the process of biological invasion, and will likely lead to conclusions that can be generalized across other urban tolerant species and biological invasions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The tropical lizard Anolis cristatellus is remarkable in that it seems to thrive in both tropical forests and intense urbanization alike. It is also a highly successful biological invader, having become established outside of its native range on numerous occasions. The research of this collaborative project has been centered on two main hypotheses. First, we hypothesized that urban lizard populations may be evolutionarily adapting to the unique challenges of city life. Urban environments differ from natural habitats in an extraordinary range of different ways.  For instance, urban areas tend to be warmer than forests, a phenomenon known as the urban heat island effect. From an arboreal lizard’s perspective, locomotion in urban habitats is also very different from running and jumping in forest. Urban surfaces tend to be broader, flatter, and smoother, and the distances between perches and refuges can be very large. Second, we hypothesized that adaptation to urban environments, if it is has occurred in this species, may have contributed to its success as a biological invader. The logic underlying this hypothesis is merely that urban areas in different places on the globe tend to be more similar than do natural habitats nearby. Thus, a lizard that has adapted to an urban habitat may find itself pre-adapted to its newfound milieu if it happens to be transported to urbanization found outside of its native range.

Over the course of this award we first provided very strong evidence suggesting that urban populations of Anolis cristatellus have indeed evolutionarily adapted to urbanization. Lizards found in cities tend to have longer limbs, as well as more subdigital scales used for clinging to smooth surfaces. These changes are exactly in the direction that one would predict based on the difference in habitat between city and forest environments. Specifically, the broad, flat surfaces of urban environments should favor lizards with long limbs as this trait facilitates rapid locomotion on flat substrates. In addition, the artificial materials than typify urban areas are much smoother than the rough substrates, such as tree bark, of forests. This should favor lizards with more adhesive scales as these should help prevent falls while climbing. Performance trials conducted under laboratory conditions strongly reinforced this interpretation. We also found that the differences in morphology between urban and natural sites persisted when lizards from each environment were bred and reared in captivity, suggesting that trait changes may be genetically-based and are thus the result of divergent evolution between habitats. We next compared thermal tolerances between lizards from urban and forest environments. Here too we found that urban and forest lizards differed in the predicted direction, with urban lizards capable of withstanding much higher temperatures than their forest counterparts. In contrast to our findings for morphology, however, this difference disappeared when lizards were acclimated to constant conditions. Though this implies that evolution of heat tolerance has not occurred in urban lizard populations, it leaves open the intriguing possibility that plasticity (the ability to respond phenotypically to environmental conditions) in thermal tolerance may facilitate use of urban areas by this species.

The hypothesis that urban adaptation has enabled biological invasion in Anolis cristatellus remains plausible, if as yet unproven. In particular, genetic data suggests that introduced populations come from within urban areas in the native range of the species. Meanwhile, urban populations are evolutionarily adapted to city life and cities in native and introduced areas pose similar challenges to lizards. On the other hand, a fine scale genetic map of native and introduced areas is still under construction, and it has not yet been possible to measure the fitness of native range urban lizards in the urban selective regime of introduced sites. Overall, however, our research clearly shows that urban lizards are evolutionarily adapting and our findings to date are consistent with the possibility that this adaptation may have facilitated biological invasion into new areas, thus linking two important dimensions of global environmental change: urbanization and biological invasions.

In addition to these major scientific aims, the project has also resulted in a number of important broader impacts relevant to science and society at large. The project has resulted in considerable student mentorship and training. Several graduate students were trained with support from this award, all of whom are either women or come from minority groups underrepresented in the sciences. Numerous undergraduate students were also trained with the support of this project, several of whom co-authored resultant scientific publications and a number of whom have continued on to masters or doctoral studies after undertaking research in my laboratory. Finally, the award supported the implementation of an undergraduate program designed to broaden participation in tropical ecology. This program was highly successful in recruiting minority students with more than half of all students in typical program years coming from groups traditionally underrepresented in science.
